title: Analysis of mouse intestinal organoid culture with conditioned media isolated from mucosal enteric glial cells

Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Part 1: Preparation of crypt organoid culture
Timing: 3 h
This protocol will allow you to establish crypt organoids from the murine small intestine. The resultant crypt suspension is mixed with Matrigel, and domes are deposited in a 24-well culture plate. After adding ENR (EGF, Noggin and R-Spondin) media, crypts develop into organoids, which contain de novo crypts and villus-like structures, recapitulating the in vivo intestine structure. For further information on the use and characterization of organoids, please refer to the previously published work (Sato et al., 2009[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib5]; Mahe et al., 2013[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib4]; Sato and Clevers, 2013[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib6]).
Part 1A: Isolation of intestinal crypts
Critical: To ensure minimal damage to the crypts, keep PBS 1×, Gut buffer, Chelating buffer and Crypt dissociation buffer on ice during the entire procedure. Have all the tools and reagents ready before sacrificing the mouse and perform the isolation on ice.
Euthanize mice using an authorized, legal method, approved by the institution where the research is conducted.
Sterilize the abdomen with 70% Ethanol.
Make an incision into the abdominal cavity from the external genitalia to the rib cage by cutting abdominal musculature on both sides.
Lift the liver and cut the intestine from the stomach at the pyloric sphincter.
Cut across the large intestine just prior to the anus to release the whole gut.
Cut the mesenteric attachment of the intestine if necessary and gently pull the gut out of the abdominal cavity (Methods video S1[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc1]A).
Place the gut in a petri dish filled with the ice-cold gut buffer.
Tear the mesentery to unfold the gut (Methods video S1[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc1]A).
Separate the small intestine from the colon by cutting the gut at the ileocecal junction (Methods video S1[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc1]A).

Flush the intestine of fecal content with the ice-cold gut buffer (Methods video S1[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc1]B) using a 1 mL syringe mounted with a 1,000 μL tip. If necessary, use forceps to gently push the feces out of the gut.
Cut the intestine into 3 equal pieces (roughly corresponding to the duodenum, jejunum, and ileum).
Cut open each segment longitudinally so that the inside of the intestine is facing up.
Use a slide to gently scrape out the villi (Methods video S2[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc2]). Discard the part of the intestinal lumen that remains on the slide.
Critical: To avoid crypt loss, scrape the intestine gently.
Place the intestinal segments in a conical 50 mL tube filled with the 20 mL gut buffer and invert gently the tube 3 times. Discard the supernatant.
Recover the intestinal segments with forceps and cut them into 0.5 cm pieces. Transfer the pieces to a 15 mL tube containing 10 mL of ice-cold chelating buffer.
Shake the tube using either an orbital shaker or a rocking plate at 4°C (fridge or cold-room) for 25 min at 20 rpm.
Gently invert the tube and filter the solution through a 100 μm strainer into a 50 mL conical tube to separate the tissue pieces from the solution containing cellular debris.
Note: We recommend keeping this solution until the end of the experiment. If the crypt isolation is successful, discard it. If the crypt isolation is not effective, check if the crypts have been lost in this suspension (see the “troubleshooting[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting]” section).
Use forceps to transfer the intestine pieces into a 50 mL conical tube containing the 25 mL ice-cold crypt dissociation buffer.

Orient the tube at 45° to the ground and shake it for 4–6 min with a gentle and regular motion (Methods video S3[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc3]). Every 2 min, place the tube on ice to rest for 30 s.

Count the number of crypts in 10 μL. The total number of crypts in the tube correspond to the number of crypts in 10 μL × 1,000.
Transfer the volume required for 300 crypts/well to a new 15 mL conical tube.
Note: For a full 24-well plate: 300 crypts × 24 wells = 7,200 crypts.
Note: If the number of crypts in 10 μL is too high and difficult to count, further dilute the crypt suspension by adding an extra 10 mL of ice-cold PBS 1X.
Centrifuge the required number of crypts at 150 g for 10 min at 4°C.

Part 1B: Crypt culture to generate organoids
On ice, mix Matrigel with ENR media at a 70:30 ratio. Use 50 μL of this 70% Matrigel per well.
Note: For a full 24-well plate: 840 μL of Matrigel + 360 μL of ENR media = 1.2 mL total.
Note: Manipulation of Matrigel should always be on ice to avoid polymerization. Pipette the Matrigel slowly to avoid introducing bubbles.
Gently resuspend crypt pellets in the required volume of 70% Matrigel until the clumps become fully dissociated.
Remove the 24-well plate from the incubator. Place a 50 μL drop gently in the center of each well.
Incubate the plate at 37°C, 5% CO2 for 15 min to allow Matrigel polymerization.
Add 350 μL of pre-warmed ENR media per well.
Culture the organoids 37°C, 5% CO2. Replace the media with fresh pre-warmed ENR media every 4 days (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]).

Part 2: Isolation and culture of mucosal enteric glial cells
Timing: 3 h

The current protocol describes the isolation of enteric glial cells from the submucosa by combining EDTA chelation with non-enzymatic dissociation. As submucosal and myenteric EGCs share the same markers, the physical separation of the epithelial mucosa from the smooth muscle was utilized to specifically isolate mucosal EGCs. Although the initial cell suspension consists of 50% mucosal EGCs and 50% other stromal cells, after 3 days in culture, EGCs represent 95% of the cells in culture. This is achieved by culture conditions favorable to EGC growth, which include EGC-friendly substrates (PDL and laminin) and GDNF supplementation (Wang et al., 2018[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib8]; Baghdadi et al., 2021[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]).
Euthanize mice using an authorized, legal method approved by the institution where the research is conducted.
Sterilize the abdomen with 70% Ethanol.
Make an incision into the abdominal cavity from the external genitalia to the rib cage by cutting abdominal musculature on both sides.
Lift the liver and cut the intestine from the stomach at the pyloric sphincter.
Cut across the large intestine just prior to the anus to release the whole gut.
Cut the mesenteric attachment of the intestine if necessary and gently pull the gut out of the abdominal cavity (Methods video S1[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc1]A).
Place the gut in a petri dish filled with the ice-cold gut buffer.
Tear the mesentery to unfold the gut (Methods video S1[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc1]A).
Note: Make sure to remove any residual mesentery from the tissue.
Separate the small intestine from the colon by cutting the gut at the ileocecal junction (Methods video S1[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc1]A).
Flush fecal content from the intestine with the ice-cold gut buffer (Methods video S1[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc1]B) using a 1 mL syringe mounted with a 1,000 μL tip.
Cut the intestine into 3 pieces (the duodenum, jejunum and ileum) and remove the longitudinal muscle.

Separate the wooden stick from the cotton tip of a cotton swab. Soak the wooden part of the cotton swab in the cold gut buffer (Methods video S4[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc4]).
Slowly thread one intestinal segment onto the pre-wetted wooden stick (Methods video S4[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc4]).
Use a scalpel or razor blade to make vertical incisions along the intestine and tease away the longitudinal muscle by applying gentle horizontal strokes using the pre-wetted cotton swab (Methods video S4[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc4]).
Sustain this motion until the longitudinal muscle peels away from the intestine. Discard the longitudinal muscle (Methods video S4[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc4]).
Note: Removing the muscle layer will discard EGCs from the myenteric plexus and avoid their contamination of the mucosal EGC culture.
Critical: Incisions should not be too deep to prevent intestinal opening.
Cut open the intestinal segment using the forceps/razor blade to release it from the cotton swab (Methods video S4[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc4]).
Keep the intestinal tissue in a 50 mL conical tube filled with the 20 mL gut buffer on ice. Repeat steps 40–43 with the two other intestinal segments.
Recover the intestinal segments with forceps and cut them into 0.5 cm pieces.
Transfer the pieces to a 50 mL conical tube filled with 25 mL of the ice-cold EGC isolation solution.
Gently shake the tube in either an orbital shaker or a rocking plate at 4°C (fridge or cold-room) for 15 min.
Triturate the tissue pieces by pipetting up and down 20 times the tissue-solution mixture using a moistened 10 mL plastic pipette.
Note: Moistening the pipette with EGC dissociation solution will avoid tissues sticking inside.
Recover the tissues by filtering the mixture through a 100 μm strainer.
Use forceps to transfer them to a new 50 mL conical tube filled with 25 mL of the ice-cold EGC isolation solution.

Repeat three times, or until the solution is clear.
Transfer tissue pieces to a 15 mL conical tube containing 10 mL of the Corning Cell Recovery solution and rock for 30 min at 4°C (cold room or fridge).
Triturate the tissue pieces by pipetting up and down 20 times the tissue-solution mixture using a moistened 5 mL plastic pipette to dissociate EGCs from the mucosa.
Filter through a 40 μm strainer in a 50 mL conical tube. Discard the tissue pieces.
Wash the strainer with 2 mL of cold PBS 1×. Transfer the flow-through to a 15 mL conical tube.
Spin at 2,000 g and 4°C for 5 min.
Gently resuspend pellets in 1 mL of EGC culture media.
Plate 330 μL of cell suspension in a well containing 170 μL of EGC culture media (PDL and laminin coated 12-well plate; 3 wells in total).
After 24 h, slowly pipette off the media containing non-adherent stromal cells.
Gently rinse with PBS 1×. Replace with fresh pre-warmed EGC culture media.
Cells can be used for experiments 3–4 days after plating (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).

Part 3: Organoid culture with enteric glial cell conditioned media
Timing: 2 h

Organoids can be combined with conditioned media from primary EGC culture. We previously demonstrated that EGC media alone are not sufficient to sustain organoid growth (Baghdadi et al., 2021[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]). Thus, we mixed 50% of EGC conditioned media (EGC-CM) with 50% of ENR organoid media. In these conditions, organoids can be expanded and passaged as usual for at least two weeks (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]). In addition, EGC-CM can also be used for organoids that have been in culture for several months with the same efficiency.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1614-Fig4.jpg
Figure 4. Organoids cultured with EGC conditioned media sustain growth and survival over time
(A) Organoids cultured with ENR:EGC-CM (50:50) for 2, 7, 10 and 14 days. Organoids were passaged on day 7 and kept in culture with EGC-CM until analysis.
(B) Quantification of the number of organoids formed per crypt 2 days after plating and culturing in EGC-CM. Scale bar, 150 μm. n=4 mice. Error bars indicate SD. n.s: non significant p value; two-tailed paired Student’s t test.
After 3–4 days of culture (following part 2: Isolation and culture of mucosal enteric glial cells[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec3.2], step 61), aspirate the EGC culture media and wash the wells twice with PBS 1×.
Add 500 μL of fresh pre-warmed EGC culture media without serum and GDNF.
Note: Removing serum is essential to avoid adding extra growth factors to organoid culture.
24 h later, collect this serum-free EGC conditioned media (EGC-CM) into a 15 mL conical tube. Pool all the wells from one mouse together.
Filter the EGC-CM through a syringe equipped with a 0.22 μm pore size filter.
Pause point: Filtered EGC-CM can be stored at −80°C for later use and thawed at 37°C for organoid culture.

Mix EGC-CM with ENR media at a 50:50 ratio: 125 μL of EGC-CM + 125 μL ENR media per well. Incubate this solution at 37°C for 10 min.
4 days after culture (following part 1: Preparation of crypt organoid culture[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec3.1], step 30), aspirate the ENR media from organoid culture.
Add 350 μL the ENR:EGC-CM mix.
Incubate the organoids at 37°C and analyze them 48 h–72 h later (see part 4: Analysis of organoids[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec3.4]).
Part 4: Analysis of organoids
One common method to analyze stem cell function using organoids is to measure the efficiency of de novo crypt formation (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]A). However, this phenotypic analysis does not allow a deep understanding of the different cell populations present in the crypts. Here, we propose two methods to assess crypt cellular composition and stem cell properties: a) RT-qPCR for transcriptional analysis (part 4A. RNA extraction for transcriptional analysis by RT-qPCR[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec3.4.1]) and b) flow cytometry for analysis of the intestinal stem cell (ISC) number (part 4B: Cellular analysis of organoids by flow cytometry[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec3.4.2]).
Part 4A. RNA extraction for transcriptional analysis by RT-qPCR
Timing: 7–8 h
Critical: RNA molecules are highly sensitive to degradation. To isolate intact, high-quality RNA, it is essential that RNases are not introduced throughout the RNA extraction procedure. Decontaminate pipettors, benchtops, centrifuge, and ice bucket with a surface decontamination solution like RNAse Away®, and use RNAse-free tips, tubes, PBS 1× and H20. In addition, the whole procedure should be done fast to avoid RNA degradation.
Following step 69, remove media from organoid culture and add 400 μL of ice-cold PBS 1× per well. Incubate the plate on ice for 5 min.
Break up the Matrigel-organoid dome by pipetting up and down.
Note: To avoid bubbles, set the pipette at 250 μL.

Pool two wells into a 15 mL conical tube filled with 5 mL of ice-cold PBS 1×. Pipette up and down with a 1,000 μL pipette 15 times to further dissociate the Matrigel.
Note: For solid statistical analysis, we recommend to pool 2 wells for one qPCR data point and use 3 data points per mouse and/or condition.
Centrifuge at 150 g for 10 min at 4°C.
Carefully discard the supernatant and resuspend the pellet in 350 μL of Qiagen RLT buffer supplemented with 1% β-mercaptoethanol.
Critical: β-mercaptoethanol is toxic and should be used in the fume hood.
Vortex the tubes for 30 s to fully lyse the organoids.
Spin the tubes at 150 g for 1 min at 4°C.
Pause point: At this step, the lysate can be transferred to a RNAse-free 1.5 mL tube, snap frozen in dry ice and kept at −80°C until ready for RNA extraction.
Proceed with the Qiagen RNeasy® Plus Mini extraction kit according to the manufacturers’ instructions: https://www.qiagen.com/us/resources/download.aspx?id=14e7cf6e-521a-4cf7-8cbc-bf9f6fa33e24&lang=en[href=https://www.qiagen.com/us/resources/download.aspx?id=14e7cf6e-521a-4cf7-8cbc-bf9f6fa33e24&lang=en].
Pause point: RNA can be kept at −80°C until ready for the reverse transcription step.
Measure RNA yield and concentration with a Nanodrop spectrophotometer.
For an optimal amplification, use ≤ 50 ng of RNA for one qPCR well.
Transfer the necessary quantity of RNA in a clean RNAse-free 1.5 mL tube.
Perform reverse transcription according to manufacturers’ guidelines: https://www.thermofisher.com/document-connect/document-connect.html?url=https%3A%2F%2Fassets.thermofisher.com%2FTFS-Assets%2FLSG%2Fmanuals%2FsuperscriptIII_man.pdf[href=https://www.thermofisher.com/document-connect/document-connect.html?url=https%3A%2F%2Fassets.thermofisher.com%2FTFS-Assets%2FLSG%2Fmanuals%2FsuperscriptIII_man.pdf].
Pause point: cDNA can be stored at −80°C until ready to load qPCR plate.
Run qPCR following manufacturers’ instructions: https://www.thermofisher.com/document-connect/document-connect.html?url=https%3A%2F%2Fassets.thermofisher.com%2FTFS-Assets%2FLSG%2Fmanuals%2Fcms_042179.pdf[href=https://www.thermofisher.com/document-connect/document-connect.html?url=https%3A%2F%2Fassets.thermofisher.com%2FTFS-Assets%2FLSG%2Fmanuals%2Fcms_042179.pdf].
Note: For 1 qPCR well: Mix 5 μL of SYBR green master mix + 4 μL cDNA + 1 μL primer mix (forward + reverse at 10 μM).
Critical: Load qPCR plate on ice.

Analyze data using the 2-ΔΔCT method (Livak and Schmittgen, 2001[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib3]). We recommend the use of two independent genes for expression normalization. First normalize the gene of interest with each housekeeping gene separately and perform the mean value of both to obtain the final 2-ΔΔCT value.
Note: Specific forward and reverse primers for commonly used crypt population markers are listed in Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1]. Tbp and Rpl13 are normalization housekeeping genes.
Part 4B: Cellular analysis of organoids by flow cytometry
Timing: 3 h
For analysis of ISCs by flow cytometry, we use crypt organoids derived from Lgr5-GFP mice (Barker et al., 2007[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib2]) for labeling ISCs and organoids from wild-type (no GFP) mice for setting up the negative staining and single stained controls (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1614-Fig5.jpg
Figure 5. Analysis of Lgr5High ISC frequency in organoids by flow cytometry
(A) Representative scheme of the experimental flow.
(B) Gating strategy to determine ISC proportion in organoids. First, doublets are gated out by FSC-H (forward scatter) versus FSC-A and then by SSC-H (side scatter) versus SSC-A gates. Second, single staining controls of PI, GFP, Epcam-APC and CD24-Pacific Blue are performed to distinguish the positive signal from the background negative signal and to evaluate if fluorescence compensation is required. After setting up all parameters (laser, compensation, positive signal), organoid samples can be analyzed. After gating on singlet, dead cells are excluded with Propidium Iodide (PI) staining. CD24 is plotted versus SSC and cells with low/medium expression of CD24 (20% of total CD24+ cells), and low granularity (40% of SSC) labeled as CD24Low/Med /SSCLow/Med are selected. From this cell population, Epcam-APC is gated versus GFP, and all the Epcam+/Lgr5-GFPHigh cells, labeled as ISCs, are selected. FACS plots were originally depicted in Baghdadi et al. (2021)[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1].
Pre-warm 5 mL of TrypLe 1× at 37°C.

Following step 69, remove media from organoid culture and add 400 μL of the ice-cold PBS 1X per well. Incubate the plate on ice for 5 min.
Break up the Matrigel-organoid dome by pipetting up and down.
Note: To avoid bubbles, set the pipette at 250 μL.
Pool all the wells for one mouse/condition into a 15 mL conical tube filled with 3 mL of ice-cold PBS 1×. Pipette up and down 15 times to further dissociate the Matrigel.
Note: Because cells will be lost during the washing steps and enzymatical dissociation, we recommend starting with minimum 6 wells of organoids for one data point.
Centrifuge at 150 g for 10 min at 4°C.
Carefully discard the supernatant and resuspend the pellet in 5 mL of pre-warmed TrypLe 1×.
Incubate the suspension at 37°C for 3 min.
Further dissociate organoids into single cells by mechanical trituration using a 5 mL syringe equipped with a 18G blunt needle. Pass the suspension 15 times through the needle.
Neutralize the TrypLe by adding 10 mL of the cold gut buffer.
Spin 400 g, 5 min at 4°C.
Resuspend the pellet in 500 μL of the gut buffer.
Add surface marker antibodies (see below) and incubate for 20 min on ice in the dark or by covering the ice bucket with an aluminum sheet.
CD24 antibody conjugated with Pacific Blue (CD24-Pacific blue): 1/500 = 1 μL in 500 μL of sample.
EPCAM antibody conjugated with APC (EPCAM-APC): 1/500 = 1 μL in 500 μL of sample.
Propidium iodide (live dye to exclude dead cells): 1/1000 = 0.5 μL in 500 μL of sample.

Note: EPCAM is used to mark all epithelial cells and CD24 to differentiate ISCs (CD24Neg) and Paneth cells (CD24High). CD24 and EPCAM can be conjugated to different fluorochromes as long as excitation and emission curves are compatible with each other and endogenous Lgr5-GFP. For fluorochrome validation and compatibility, use the BD spectrum viewer[href=https://www.bdbiosciences.com/en-us/resources/bd-spectrum-viewer].
Critical: Set aside 50 μL of control sample before adding antibodies: it will be used as a GFP single stained control to set up the cytometer parameters.
Add 5 mL of the gut buffer to wash off the excess antibody.
Spin at 400 g for 5 min at 4°C.
Discard the supernatant. Resuspend the pellet in 500 μL of the gut buffer.
Proceed to flow cytometry acquisition and analysis (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]B).
